We start with the decay at rest:

  π⁺ → μ⁺ + ν

Since the π⁺ is at rest its energy is just its rest mass energy, mπ = 139.6 MeV. The μ⁺ has rest mass mμ = 105.7 MeV and the neutrino is (for our purposes) massless.

Conservation of energy gives:
  mπ = Eμ + Eν,
and conservation of momentum tells us that the μ⁺ and the neutrino have equal and opposite momenta, p.

Since for the μ⁺
  Eμ = √(mμ² + p²)
and the neutrino (massless) has energy
  Eν = p,
we have
  √(105.7² + p²) + p = 139.6.

A standard approach is to use the two‐body decay formulas. For a two–body decay with a massless neutrino, the energy of the charged muon is given by
  Eμ = (mπ² + mμ²) / (2mπ).

Calculating:
  Eμ = (139.6² + 105.7²) / (2 × 139.6).
Compute the squares:
  139.6² ≈ 19488.16,
  105.7² ≈ 11170.49.
Thus,
  Eμ = (19488.16 + 11170.49) / 279.2
    = 30658.65 / 279.2 ≈ 109.8 MeV.
Then the kinetic energy (KE) of the muon is
  KEμ = Eμ – mμ ≈ 109.8 – 105.7 = 4.1 MeV.
Since the total available energy difference from rest masses is mπ – mμ = 33.9 MeV the neutrino gets
  KEν ≈ 33.9 – 4.1 = 29.8 MeV.

Now, none of the provided options list kinetic energies of approximately 4.1 MeV and 29.8 MeV for the muon and neutrino respectively. The totals in the provided choices do not add up to the available 33.9 MeV either.

Therefore, none of the answers A), B), or C) match our results.

Under hydrogenation with Pd/C in methanol, addition of one equivalent of H₂ will typically reduce the exocyclic alkene (the more accessible, less hindered double bond) leaving the cyclic (endocyclic) double bond untouched. In other words, product 1 is 1-methyl-4-(isopropyl)cyclohexene.

Next, treatment of 1 with 3‑chloroperbenzoic acid (mCPBA) leads to epoxidation of the remaining cyclic alkene. This gives product 2, an epoxide bridging what were originally C1 and C2. (Remember that the C1 carbon bears a methyl group and C2 has only hydrogens so it is less substituted.)

Then, upon treatment of the epoxide 2 with sodium methoxide, the nucleophilic methoxide opens the epoxide preferentially at the less hindered carbon (C2). This ring opening occurs by backside (SN2) attack so that the O– (coming from the epoxide) remains attached to C1, which then is protonated to give an OH. As a result, product 3 displays an OH at C1 (which still retains its original methyl substituent), and a methoxy group attached to C2; the isopropyl group at C4 remains unchanged.

Finally, reaction of 3 with propanoic acid, dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC), and a catalytic amount of 4‑dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) leads to esterification of the free OH group at C1 to yield a propionate ester. Thus, product 4 is a cyclohexyl propionate in which the C1 position has become a propionate ester (and still bears a methyl substituent), the C2 bears a methoxy group (from the ring‐opening step), and the C4 carries the isopropyl group.

We must first understand what happens in the experiment. When using only paraformaldehyde (PFA) for fixation, the usually “looser” fixation may allow some transient or indirect protein–DNA associations to be captured. Using a second, protein–protein crosslinker such as DSG (disuccinimidyl glutarate) creates a more stringent cross‐linking environment that helps distinguish between bona fide direct binding events and those that might have been indirectly “caught” with only PFA. In some ChIP experiments this results in the disappearance of peaks that were present with only PFA fixation.

In the case of IKAROS in human B cells, past literature has revealed that many of the disappearing peaks seen using only PFA fixation tend to occur in regions associated with very large genes. These regions—often in the introns—can be “hyper‐ChIPable” loci, that is, they non‐specifically attract signal because of their open chromatin state and complex transcriptional activity. When a more stringent fixation (PFA+DSG) is used, the artifactual interactions are less readily captured, causing those ChIP peaks to vanish.

Thus, step by step, the evidence leads us to conclude that the disappearing peaks are most likely found in the introns of large genes.

The probability a planet will transit its star scales approximately as the ratio of the star’s radius to the orbital separation (R★/a). For circular orbits, the semi‐major axis “a” can be determined from Kepler’s Third Law, which tells us that a ∝ P^(2/3)·M★^(1/3).

Let’s denote the two cases as follows:

• Planet₁: orbiting a star of mass M₁ = 2M₂ (where M₂ is the mass of the second star) with an orbital period P₁ = P₂/3.
• Planet₂: orbiting a star of mass M₂ with period P₂.

Since both stars have the same radius, the transit probability is proportional to 1/a.

For Planet₁:
 a₁ ∝ (P₁)^(2/3) · (M₁)^(1/3)
   = (P₂/3)^(2/3) · (2M₂)^(1/3)
   = P₂^(2/3) · (1/3^(2/3)) · 2^(1/3) · M₂^(1/3)

For Planet₂:
 a₂ ∝ (P₂)^(2/3) · M₂^(1/3)

So the ratio of the separations is:
 a₂/a₁ = [P₂^(2/3)·M₂^(1/3)] / [P₂^(2/3)·M₂^(1/3)/(3^(2/3)·2^(1/3))]
     = 3^(2/3) / 2^(1/3)

Numerically,
 3^(2/3) ≈ 2.08 and 2^(1/3) ≈ 1.26,
so
 a₂/a₁ ≈ 2.08/1.26 ≈ 1.65.

Since the transit probability is ∝ 1/a, Planet₁’s transit probability is about 1.65 times that of Planet₂. None of the answer choices list this ratio (they mention ≈2.25, 1.5, or 2.7 times), and the ones that favor either planet do so with different factors.

Thus the correct conclusion is that none of the available answer choices exactly match the computed result.

The reaction is

  CaEDTA ⇌ Ca²⁺ + EDTA⁴⁻

with the formation (binding) constant given by

  K = [CaEDTA]⁄([Ca²⁺][EDTA⁴⁻]) = 5×10¹⁰

We start with 0.02 M CaEDTA. Suppose a small amount x (in M) of CaEDTA dissociates so that

  [Ca²⁺] = x  and  [EDTA⁴⁻] = x

and the remaining CaEDTA concentration is

  [CaEDTA] = 0.02 – x ≈ 0.02     (since x will be very small given the large constant).

Plugging into the equilibrium expression:

  (0.02 – x)/(x²) ≈ 0.02/(x²) = 5×10¹⁰

Solving for x:

  x² = 0.02/(5×10¹⁰) = (2×10⁻²)/(5×10¹⁰) = 4×10⁻¹³

Taking the square root:

  x = √(4×10⁻¹³) = 2×10⁻⁶.5 ≈ 6.3×10⁻⁷ M

Thus, the free calcium ion concentration is approximately 6.3×10⁻⁷ M. Comparing with the given choices (2.0×10⁻² M; 5.0×10⁻³ M; 1.0×10⁻² M), none of these match our calculated result.

We want to arrive at the idea that the “impulse” approximation means we assume that a nucleon struck by an external probe behaves essentially as if it were a free particle. To do that typically one assumes:

• (1) The probe only “sees” one nucleon at a time (that is, the full many‐body current is replaced by the sum of independent one–body currents).

• (2) The rest of the nucleus does not disturb the process – in other words the nucleus is “transparent” so that any effects from the other nucleons (including final state interactions) are neglected.

• (4) The bound nucleon is treated as if there were no binding forces acting on it so that its response is the same as a free nucleon.

These three assumptions (1, 2, and 4) are what allow you to approximate the response of a bound nucleon by its free response.

Assumption (3), that the quarks internal to the selected nucleon are non–relativistic, is not central to the impulse approximation. It is more a statement about the internal dynamics of the nucleon rather than about how the external interaction sees the nucleon in the many–body environment.

Looking at the answer choices, none of them lists 1, 2, and 4 exactly. Option B gives (2,3,4), Option C gives (1,2,3), and Option D gives (1,3,4). Since the impulse approximation relies on (1), (2) and (4), none of the answer options matches the needed set.

We have an ether in which an aryl oxygen is bound to an allylic‐type substituent. (Its structure is Ph–O–CH2–C(CH3)2–CH=CH2.) When such ethers are treated with HX, there are two competing processes. In “normal” ether cleavage the protonated ether “breaks” at the sp³–O bond and one would get an alkyl halide plus phenol. However, when the alkyl fragment is an allylic (or otherwise “cation‐stabilized”) group – and especially when it is hindered on the alkyl side – the reaction often runs by an ionization (SN1) pathway. In that case the protonated ether loses the alkyl part to give an allylic-type carbocation. Because the departing group is now “free” and the other product is phenol (which is quite nucleophilic, particularly at its ortho and para positions) the ion may “rebound” by attacking a second molecule of phenol in a Friedel–Crafts type reaction. (This kind of reaction is conceptually related to the well‐known Claisen rearrangement – though here the cleavage and electrophilic aromatic alkylation occur under acidic conditions.) 

A key point is that in the initially generated allylic cation the double bond is “lost” (or more exactly, it is converted during the formation of a saturated, rearranged cation) so that, after bromide does its part (or after a simple deprotonation), one obtains an alkyl group that is no longer unsaturated. Moreover, because phenol is activated for electrophilic aromatic substitution at both the ortho and para positions, attack by the carbocation can take place at either site. Thus one obtains a mixture of o‐ and p–alkylated phenols, where the new alkyl side‐chain is now the saturated 2,2–dimethylbutyl group.

Thus the two products are 2-(2,2-dimethylbutyl)phenol and 4-(2,2-dimethylbutyl)phenol.

We can “unpack” one typical pinacol rearrangement by considering that when a vicinal diol is protonated under acidic conditions one –OH is protonated and leaves as water to give a carbocation. Then a neighboring substituent (the best “migratory” group – usually an arenyl group because it helps stabilize positive charge by resonance – moves with its bonding electrons into the empty orbital. The new oxonium ion then deprotonates to form a carbonyl. (In effect the overall process “relocates” a substituent from one carbon to the other, forming a rearranged ketone.) 

Let’s consider briefly the three cases:

Compound A, 3‑methyl‐4‑phenylhexane‑3,4‑diol, is drawn as a six‐carbon chain with an –OH at C‑3 (which bears a methyl) and an –OH at C‑4 (which bears a phenyl). In a typical pinacol rearrangement one chooses the site where water leaves to generate the more-stabilized carbocation – often the one adjacent to the aryl group. Then migration of (here) the “phenyl” group to the cation is preferred. After reorganization and formation of the carbonyl the overall skeleton “contracts” (or is renumbered) so that one obtains the ketone identified as 2‑methyl‑1‑phenylbutan‑1‑one.

Similarly, compound B, 3‑(4‑hydroxyphenyl)‑2‑phenylpentane‑2,3‑diol reacts under acid to eventually yield a rearranged ketone. Through protonation of one –OH, water loss and then migration of the aryl group (here the 4‑hydroxyphenyl group migrates preferentially because of its enhanced donating effect), one obtains the product 2‑(4‑hydroxyphenyl)‑1‑phenylbutan‑1‑one.

Now compound C, 1,1,2‑tris(4‑methoxyphenyl)‑2‑phenylethane‑1,2‑diol, has on one carbon two 4‑methoxyphenyl groups and on the adjacent carbon a 4‑methoxyphenyl AND a phenyl. Under acidic conditions the reaction is expected to follow a path in which the best‐stabilized carbocation is generated. When water leaves from the appropriate carbon, then the best migratory group – namely one of the strongly donating 4‑methoxyphenyl groups – moves. That migration leads finally to the formation of a carbonyl on the carbon which (after rearrangement) ends up carrying three 4‑methoxyphenyl substituents, with the phenyl ending up on the “other” carbon. This structure is named as 2,2,2‑tris(4‑methoxyphenyl)‑1‑phenylethan‑1‑one.

Comparing the answer choices:

• Option B gives for A and B the products 2‑methyl‑1‑phenylbutan‑1‑one and 2‑(4‑hydroxyphenyl)‑1‑phenylbutan‑1‑one – which are the expected ones – but it gives for C a product with “1,2,2‑tris(4‑methoxyphenyl)‑2‑phenylethan‑1‑one” that implies the carbonyl and the aryl groups are arranged on opposite carbons from what the migration‐scenario predicts.

• Option D gives exactly A and B as in Option B, but for C it gives “2,2,2‑tris(4‑methoxyphenyl)‑1‑phenylethan‑1‑one” which fits the mechanism in which water departs from the diol carbon bearing two 4‑methoxyphenyl groups, so that migration of one 4‑methoxyphenyl from the adjacent center brings the total to three on the ketone carbon (with the phenyl left on the other carbon).

Step–by–step mechanistic reasoning therefore leads to the answer given in option D.

We are given a wave function ψ(x) = (a/√(1+x)) – 0.5i, defined (non-zero) only in the interval x = 1 to 3. In quantum mechanics the wave function must be normalized so that

  ∫₁³ |ψ(x)|² dx = 1

where |ψ(x)|² is the modulus squared of ψ(x). Writing ψ(x) as u(x) + iv with

  u(x) = a/√(1+x)  and  v = –0.5

the modulus squared is

  |ψ(x)|² = u(x)² + v² = a²/(1+x) + 0.25

The normalization condition becomes

  ∫₁³ [a²/(1+x) + 0.25] dx = 1

We can split this integral into two parts:

  a² ∫₁³ 1/(1+x) dx + 0.25 ∫₁³ dx = 1

First, calculate the integrals:

1. For I₁ = ∫₁³ 1/(1+x) dx, make the substitution u = 1+x; then du = dx, and when x = 1, u = 2; when x = 3, u = 4. Thus:
  I₁ = ∫₂⁴ 1/u du = ln|u| evaluated from 2 to 4 = ln(4) – ln(2) = ln(4/2) = ln2

2. For I₂ = ∫₁³ dx = 3 – 1 = 2

Then the normalization condition is:

  a² (ln2) + 0.25(2) = 1
  a² (ln2) + 0.5 = 1

Solve for a²:

  a² (ln2) = 0.5  ⇒  a² = 0.5/ln2

Now, using ln2 ≈ 0.693, we obtain:

  a² ≈ 0.5/0.693 ≈ 0.721  ⇒  a ≈ √(0.721) ≈ 0.849

This numerical value (approximately 0.849) does not match any of the provided options (1.1, 0.35, 0.6) exactly. Therefore, none of the options is correct.

We first note that a spin‐1/2 particle is a fermion, so no two particles (including their spin labels) can share the same quantum state. In a one‐dimensional infinite well the allowed one‐particle energy levels are

  Eₙ = n²E   (with E = π²ℏ²/(2mL²) and n = 1, 2, 3, …).

Because each level n can hold two particles (one with spin ↑ and one with spin ↓), when we have four identical fermions the lowest (“ground‐state”) configuration is obtained by “filling” the lowest “slots.” That is, two particles go into the n = 1 level and the remaining two go into the n = 2 level. Thus:

  Ground state total energy = 2·(1²E) + 2·(2²E) = 2E + 8E = 10E.

For the many–body “excitations” the lowest excited state is obtained by promoting a single particle from its originally occupied level to the next available level so as to minimize the extra energy. There are two likely one–particle promotions to consider:
 1. Promoting one particle from n = 2 to n = 3
  – Occupancies: n = 1 has 2, n = 2 has 1, and n = 3 has 1.
  – Total energy = 2·(1²E) + 1·(2²E) + 1·(3²E) = 2E + 4E + 9E = 15E.
 2. Promoting one particle from n = 1 to n = 3
  – Occupancies: n = 1 has 1, n = 2 has 2, and n = 3 has 1.
  – Total energy = 1·(1²E) + 2·(2²E) + 1·(3²E) = 1E + 8E + 9E = 18E.

Since 15E is lower than 18E, the first excited many–body state has total energy 15E.

Now, for the second excited state we must look for the next configuration (the next higher total energy). One candidate is the promotion of the particle from n = 1 to n = 3 (giving total energy 18E as calculated), while another possibility (for example, promoting one particle from n = 2 to n = 4) gives even higher energies. Hence, the ordering of the lowest states is:
 • Ground state: 10E
 • First excited state: 15E
 • Second excited state: 18E

Looking at the answer choices provided:

 A) 30E, 39E, 50E
 B) 4E, 10E, 50E
 C) 4E, 10E, 15E
 D) There is no correct answer

None of these choices match the values (10E, 15E, 18E) we have calculated. Therefore, the correct choice is:

  RCH=CHR  + CH₂=CH₂

so that aside from ethene the only new product is the “dimer” RCH=CHR.

Let’s now consider our substrate, 3‐methylpent‐1‐ene. Its structure is

  CH₂=CH–CH(CH₃)–CH₂–CH₃

It bears a remote stereocenter at C3 (–CH(CH₃)–) and is provided as the racemate. In the metathesis the double‐bond “ends” of two molecules come together so that the new product is

  [CH(CH(CH₃)–CH₂CH₃)]CH=CH[CH(CH₃)–CH₂CH₃].

Since the reaction couples “two copies” of the same alkyl fragment, one might wonder whether the chirality of the remote center “matters.”

Here is the key point. Although the starting material is racemic, when two molecules combine the “dimer” has two –CH(CH₃)–CH₂CH₃ substituents on either side of the new C=C. (a) If two molecules of the same stereochemistry combine – say two “R‐molecules” – the two substituents are identical. (Even though the two enantiomeric choices, R and S, can be formed in separate events, a mixture of (R,R)– and (S,S)–couplings is obtained; since each enantiomeric pair is obtained as a racemate they are not “different” products for most practical purposes.) (b) If one “R–molecule” couples with one “S–molecule” then the two sides are “enantiomeric” (mirror images) to one another. In a symmetric molecule of the type RCH=CHR the two sides must be identical; in effect the cross–coupling forces the two halves to “match.” (Thus the heterocoupling yields a product that is not diastereomeric with the product coming from the homo–coupling.)

In other words, though there is in principle the possibility of four combinations (two for one position times two for the other), the symmetry of the dimer means that the two possibilities collapse into just two distinct products (each of which, if isolated, would be obtained as a racemic mixture or in the case of the “matched” coupling, as an achiral product). In addition, while the newly formed alkene could in principle be “E” or “Z,” it is well known that Grubbs catalysts favor the thermodynamically more stable (typically “E”) alkene. (Even if a small amount of the “Z” isomer were formed, it would be in equilibrium with the “E” isomer.) Thus when one asks “how many possible products (excluding ethene) are there?” the answer is that metathesis of rac‐3–methylpent‐1–ene leads (by self‐metathesis) to just ONE dimeric “skeleton” whose stereochemical outcome falls into two groups: one set coming from homo–coupling (R+R and S+S give the same product, though as a racemic pair) and a second from hetero–coupling (R+S gives an achiral or meso compound). (Any “E/Z” isomerism is rendered moot by the fact that the catalyst very likely gives only the thermodynamic alkene.) 

Thus, under typical Grubbs–catalyzed conditions the only “new” metathesis product (besides ethene) is the dimer – and it exists in two forms that are different with respect to the relative configuration of the remote stereocenters.

We will show how one may “un‐ravel” the transformation step–by–step.

Let’s briefly outline one accepted interpretation. (Note that under “bromination–then–base” conditions one may have two competing reactions. Under “vigorous” heating with NaOH an α‐bromoketone can “Favorskii rearrange” rather than simply eliminating HBr. In many textbook problems the “ring contraction” outcome is “the” answer.) 

Step 1. Cyclohexanone is treated with Br₂ so that bromination occurs at an α–carbon, giving 2–bromocyclohexanone (product 1).

Step 2. On heating with NaOH the α–bromoketone may undergo a Favorskii rearrangement. In this rearrangement the base deprotonates one of the “other” α–hydrogens so that an intramolecular displacement gives a cyclopropanone intermediate. Ring–opening of that intermediate leads to contraction of the six–membered ring to a five–membered ring and formation of a carboxylate. (Had simple “elimination” occurred one would get an enone; but many problems of this type are designed to deliver the rearranged product.) Thus product 2 is (after work–up) cyclopentanecarboxylic acid.

Step 3. Treatment of the acid with thionyl chloride (SOCl₂) in the presence of pyridine converts the carboxylic acid to its corresponding acid chloride (product 3).

Step 4. Finally, reduction of an acid chloride with lithium tri–tert–butoxyaluminum hydride [LiAlH(O–tBu)₃] stops at the aldehyde stage. Thus product 4 is cyclopentanecarboxaldehyde.

Now let’s “count” the chemically non–equivalent hydrogen atoms in cyclopentanecarboxaldehyde. (In NMR terms, “chemically distinct” means different “proton environments”.)

The structure may be drawn as a cyclopentane ring carrying a –CHO group (the formyl group) at one ring–carbon. (Because the Favorskii rearrangement “places” the –COOH exocyclic on a ring carbon, subsequent reduction gives an aldehyde attached to a cyclopentyl ring.) One may number the ring so that the carbon bearing the –CHO is “C1.”

A. The –CHO group itself has one hydrogen (and that proton is in a very peculiar environment by itself).

B. The “substituted” ring–carbon (C1) now is bonded to the formyl group, to two ring carbons, and to one hydrogen. Thus its (unique) hydrogen is in its own environment.

C. The two carbons adjacent to C1 (namely C2 and C5) normally “see” the influence of the substituent. In a 1–substituted cyclopentane the circuit of bonds shows that the two “neighbors” are equivalent by symmetry. However, each –CH₂ group is attached to a stereogenic center (C1) so its two hydrogens become diastereotopic – that is, they are chemically different. But because the two carbons are “paired” by symmetry the two “left–side” positions (one on C2 and the corresponding one on C5) turn out to be equivalent; and likewise the complementary set (the “other” proton on each CH₂ group) are equivalent. Thus the two CH₂ groups together provide 2 chemically distinct proton types (each type accounts for 2 hydrogens, total 4 H).

D. The two “remaining” ring carbons (C3 and C4) are likewise equivalent by symmetry to each other. Each –CH₂ here again has a pair of diastereotopic hydrogens. In the pair as a whole the two “sub–groups” will be different. Thus C3/C4 together account for 2 more chemically distinct proton types (again, each type having 2 hydrogens, total 4 H).

Altogether, if one “counts” the individual hydrogens then the tally is:
 – the formyl proton: 1 
 – the unique (CH) proton on the substituted carbon: 1 
 – 4 hydrogens from the two equivalent CH₂ groups at C2/C5 (but appearing as 2 distinct sets because of diastereotopicity): 4 
 – 4 hydrogens from the two equivalent CH₂ groups at C3/C4 (again 2 different sets): 4 
When summed the total number of hydrogen atoms present is 1 + 1 + 4 + 4 = 10.

In many such problems one sometimes “merges” the two diastereotopic hydrogens on each CH₂ if one is asked “how many types of carbon–bound hydrogens appear” (which then would be 4 types). But here the wording “chemically distinct hydrogen atoms” is best interpreted as “how many hydrogens are in environments that differ from every other hydrogen in the molecule” – and by that count the “individual” hydrogens add up to 10.

Thus the answer is 10.

We can “solve” the problem by using the well‐known image–charge method. (I emphasize that the answer must be obtained by a “half‐interaction” prescription; see, for example, Jackson’s Electrodynamics.) Here is one acceptable derivation.

Suppose we have a grounded conducting sphere of radius R (centered at the origin) and a point charge q located a distance d from the center (with d > R). One may show that the potential in the region outside the sphere (which is at zero potential) is identical to that produced by the two “image” charges:
  • the real charge q at r = d,
  • an image charge
   q′ = –(qR/d)
located at r = a where
  a = R²/d.
That is, the distance between the two charges is
  |d – a| = d – (R²/d) = (d² – R²)/d.

Because the image method “mirrors” the effect of the induced charges, the work to bring the real charge from infinity into its position is given by only one‐half the interaction energy between q and q′ (the “1/2” avoids double–counting the mutual energy when the “source” is not really present). Thus one writes

  U = ½ · [interaction energy between q and q′]
    = ½ · k · [q·q′/(distance between them)]
    = ½ · k · [q·(–qR/d)  ÷ ((d² – R²)/d)]
    = – ½ · k · (q²R/d) · [d/(d²–R²)]
    = – ½ · k · (q²R/(d²–R²)) .

That is, the net potential energy is

  U = – (1/2)·k·(q² R)/(d² – R²).

Now compare with the given answer choices:
  A) – (½) kq² d/(d² + R²)
  B) – kq² d/(d² – R²)
  C) – (½) kq² R²/(d² – R²)
  D) There is no correct answer

The answer we obtained has a numerator proportional to R (and a factor ½), not d (as in A or B) or R² (as in C). Hence none of the answer choices exactly agrees with the correct expression.

Thus, the correct response is:

We start with the fact that in local‐thermodynamic–equilibrium the ratio of two atomic level populations is set by the Boltzmann factor. In other words, for two levels 1 and 2 the ratio is

  n₂/n₁ = (g₂/g₁) exp[–(ΔE)/(kT)],

where ΔE is the energy difference between the two levels, k is Boltzmann’s constant, and T the local temperature. (The statistical weights g₁ and g₂ are assumed not to change when spots are present.) For our purposes the “observed” ratio for the whole star will depend on the local temperature.

When the star is unspotted the photosphere is at 6000 K, so the ratio is

  R₆₀₀₀ = constant × exp[–ΔE/(k·6000)].

When 40% of the surface is spotted the mean “effective” temperature determined from the overall flux is 5500 K. (One might be tempted to “average” the Boltzmann factors over the two regions; however, in this problem the intended assumption is that the measured photospheric ratio is similar in form to that of a star with a uniform temperature equal to T_eff = 5500 K.) In that case the ratio becomes

  R₅₅₀₀ = constant × exp[–ΔE/(k·5500)].

Thus the factor by which the ratio when the star does not have spots is larger than when it has spots is

  R₆₀₀₀ / R₅₅₀₀ = exp{ –ΔE/(k·6000) + ΔE/(k·5500) }
            = exp[ΔE/k (1/5500 – 1/6000)].

The transition in question corresponds to a wavelength of about 1448 Å. Using ΔE ≈ hc/λ, we compute

  ΔE = (6.626×10⁻²⁷ erg·s × 3×10¹⁰ cm/s) / (1448×10⁻⁸ cm)
    ≈ 1.37×10⁻¹¹ erg.

And with Boltzmann’s constant k ≈ 1.38×10⁻¹⁶ erg/K, one finds

  ΔE/k ≈ (1.37×10⁻¹¹) / (1.38×10⁻¹⁶) ≈ 10⁵ K.

Now, the ratio factor becomes

  R₆₀₀₀/R₅₅₀₀ = exp[10⁵ × (1/5500 – 1/6000)].

Evaluating the temperature difference term:

  1/5500 ≈ 1.8182×10⁻⁴, 1/6000 ≈ 1.6667×10⁻⁴,
  so  1/5500 – 1/6000 ≈ 1.515×10⁻⁵.

Thus,

  R₆₀₀₀/R₅₅₀₀ = exp(10⁵ × 1.515×10⁻⁵)
            = exp(1.515)
            ≈ 4.55.

None of the answer choices A (∼1.1), B (∼7.8), or D (∼2.9) are close to 4.55. Therefore the only acceptable answer is the “none” option.

We can show that the “3s‐to–1s two–dipole cascade” must proceed via the 2p level. In the usual notation the 3s state is written as

  |3,0,0⟩

and the 1s state as

  |1,0,0⟩.

A dipole (E1) photon carries angular momentum 1 and so the selection rules for an electric–dipole transition require

  Δl = ±1 and Δm = 0, ±1.

Thus the first dipole jump from |3,0,0⟩ (l = 0, m = 0) may only go to a state |n,1,m⟩ with l = 1 and m = –1, 0 or 1. In our case the only “allowed” intermediate state is the 2p level,
  |2,1,m⟩, with m = –1, 0 or 1.

Then the second dipole jump from |2,1,m⟩ to |1,0,0⟩ again must satisfy Δl = ±1 and Δm = 0, ±1. (For example, if the intermediate state is |2,1,0⟩ then we must have q = 0 so that m_final = 0 + 0 = 0; if one has m = 1 then one must have q = –1, etc.) 

A short calculation shows that if one evaluates the relevant Clebsch–Gordan coefficients the “angular‐parts” of the dipole matrix elements give identical weights (up to the usual irrelevance of overall phase) for all three allowed values of m. (In other words, the “3s → 2p” de–excitation takes place with equal probability into each of the three magnetic substates of the 2p level, and then each of these decays to |1,0,0⟩ with its own allowed quantum–mechanical amplitude.) In a fully correct treatment the three “routes”
  |3,0,0⟩ → |2,1,–1⟩ → |1,0,0⟩,
  |3,0,0⟩ → |2,1,0⟩ → |1,0,0⟩,
  |3,0,0⟩ → |2,1,1⟩ → |1,0,0⟩
must be added incoherently (since the intermediate 2p substates are “observably different” by their magnetic quantum numbers) and one finds that their relative probabilities are equal.

Thus no single one of the answers (B, C or D) – which single‐out only one intermediate channel with a quoted probability – is correct. (One might even quote branching “fractions” 1/3, 1/3 and 1/3 for the three routes.)

We wish to compute the forward‐direction (θ = 0) scattering amplitude from the phase‐shift data. In a partial–wave analysis the scattering amplitude is given by

  f(θ) = 1/(2ik) Σₗ (2l + 1) [e^(2iδₗ) – 1] Pₗ(cos θ).

Since Pₗ(1) = 1, the amplitude in the forward (incident‐beam) direction is

  f(0) = 1/(2ik) Σₗ (2l + 1) [e^(2iδₗ) – 1].

Because the two forms

  e^(2iδₗ) – 1 = 2i e^(iδₗ) sin δₗ                (1)
  f(0) = (1/k) Σₗ (2l + 1) e^(iδₗ) sin δₗ            (2)

are equivalent, one may show (by writing the complex exponential in (2) as cos δₗ + i sin δₗ) that the imaginary part of f(0) is given by

  Im f(0) = (1/k) Σₗ (2l + 1) sin²δₗ.

The experiment tells us that only the first five partial waves (l = 0, 1, …, 4) contribute and gives

  δ₀ = 90°, δ₁ = 67°, δ₂ = 55°, δ₃ = 30°, δ₄ = 13°.

It is important to work in radians when using trigonometric functions. (For example, 90° = π/2 rad.) Let us compute the contributions term‐by‐term (keeping in mind that sin δ means sin (δ in radians); note that for angles in degrees the numerical values are as follows approximately):

  sin 90° = 1       → sin²90° = 1.
  sin 67° ≈ 0.9205    → sin²67° ≈ 0.8473.
  sin 55° ≈ 0.8192    → sin²55° ≈ 0.6710.
  sin 30° = 0.5       → sin²30° = 0.25.
  sin 13° ≈ 0.225     → sin²13° ≈ 0.0506.

Now, including the weight factor (2l + 1) for each l we have

  l = 0: (1) × 1.0000 = 1.0000
  l = 1: (3) × 0.8473 = 2.5419
  l = 2: (5) × 0.6710 = 3.3550
  l = 3: (7) × 0.25   = 1.7500
  l = 4: (9) × 0.0506 = 0.4554

The total sum S is

  S = 1.0000 + 2.5419 + 3.3550 + 1.7500 + 0.4554 ≈ 9.1023.

Thus

  Im f(0) = (1/k) S = (9.1023)/k.

Now, what is k? For scattering the “wave‐number” k is given by
  k = p/ħ,
with p the momentum of the incident electron. At 50 MeV kinetic energy the electron is highly relativistic. (In fact, an electron’s rest–energy is only about 0.511 MeV.) In our units (with ħc = 197.327 MeV·fm) the momentum is approximately
  p ≈ 50 MeV/c   →  k ≈ 50/197.327 ≈ 0.2533 fm⁻¹.

Thus

  Im f(0) ≈ 9.1023/0.2533 ≈ 35.94 fm.

Let's consider each theory:

• Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is a quantum field theory and, like most such theories, shows ultraviolet divergences at high energies that must be treated by regulators before renormalization is applied.

• Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) also contains ultraviolet divergences in its loop integrals and relies on regularization procedures as part of its renormalization process.

• Classical Electrodynamics, in contrast, is a classical theory. It does not involve the integration over high‐momentum virtual particles that lead to ultraviolet divergences in quantum theories. Although issues like the infinite self‐energy of a point charge appear, these are typically not handled by “regularization” in a quantum field theory sense.

Given the options, classical electrodynamics never requires regularization at high energies in the same manner as the quantum field theories.

Let’s analyze the sequence step‐by‐step.

1. Benzene reacts with concentrated HNO₃/H₂SO₄. This is a nitration so benzene is converted into nitrobenzene (product 1).

2. When nitrobenzene is treated with Br₂ together with Fe powder, a bromination occurs. Because the –NO₂ group is strongly deactivating and directs electrophilic substitution to the meta–position, the bromine is introduced at the position meta to the nitro group. That is, product 2 is m–bromonitrobenzene.

3. Next, treatment of product 2 with H₂ in the presence of Pd/C reduces the nitro group to an amino group without affecting the bromine. Thus product 3 is m–bromoaniline (the –NH₂ group is at the position that originally carried –NO₂, and the bromine remains meta to it).

4. The m–bromoaniline (product 3) is then treated with NaNO₂ and HBF₄. These conditions diazotize the amino group, forming the corresponding diazonium salt (product 4) that still has the bromine in the meta position relative to where –NH₂ (now –N₂⁺) was.

5. Finally, product 4 is heated and then reacted with anisole. Under these conditions the arenediazonium salt undergoes a coupling (a version of the Gomberg–Bachmann reaction) with the electron–rich anisole. Anisole, being activated by its –OCH₃ group, is attacked preferentially at its para–position. Thus the new C–C bond is formed between the aryl group which had the diazonium group (with its bromine in the meta–position relative to the former –NH₂) and the para–position of anisole. In the final product (product 5) the ring coming from nitrobenzene now bears a bromine in the position meta to the biaryl linkage, while the anisole ring carries its –OCH₃ group (with the bond attached para to it). In other words, product 5 is 3–bromo–4′–methoxy–1,1′–biphenyl.

None of the answer choices exactly state “3–bromo–4′–methoxy–1,1′–biphenyl”. Choice A has a fluoro substituent instead of a methoxy group; choice B places the bromine on the anisole ring and gives an unusual numbering; and choice D shows a bromine para to the biaryl bond (4–bromo) rather than meta (3–bromo).

Thus, in view of the options provided, none of them exactly match the product obtained from the sequence.

In the “quantum rotation–vibration” (or non‐rigid rotor) model the molecule in its absolute ground state is in the vibrational and rotational ground state (n = 0, J = 0). Although a change in the rotational state from J = 0 to J = 1 (with ΔE_rot = 2B, where B = ℏ²/(2I)) is the smallest energy jump from J = 0, one finds that for typical diatomics the magnitude of ΔE_rot is on the order of 10⁻²²–10⁻²³ J.   ℏ = 1.05457×10⁻³⁴ J·s,
  so  ΔE_vib = (1.05457×10⁻³⁴ J·s) × (4×10¹⁴ rad/s) ≈ 4.218×10⁻²⁰ J.

Since the vibrational spacing is much larger than the rotational spacing and because the problem quotes ω, it is clear that the photon absorption under consideration is the vibrational excitation from n = 0 to n = 1. When a photon is absorbed, apart from contributing its energy ΔE its momentum p must also be “absorbed” (recoil). For a photon its momentum is given by

  p = E/c.

Thus, substituting the vibrational energy:
  p = ΔE_vib / c ≈ (4.218×10⁻²⁰ J) / (3×10⁸ m/s) ≈ 1.406×10⁻²⁸ N·s.

and the total energy is:

  P(150) = 1 – e^(–λ×150)
       = 1 – e^(ln(0.68)×150/100)
       = 1 – (0.68)^(1.5).

Calculating (0.68)^(1.5):
  (0.68)^(1.5) = exp(1.5 × ln0.68) ≈ exp(1.5 × (–0.38566)) ≈ exp(–0.57849) ≈ 0.561.
So the probability is
  1 – 0.561 ≈ 0.439, i.e. about 44%.

We start by recalling that for a point charge whose retarded‐time position is s(tr) and whose velocity at that retarded time is v, the well–known Liénard–Wiechert potentials are (in SI):

  V(r,t) = [q/(4πε₀)] 1/[(1 – n·(v/c))R]        (1)
  A(r,t) = [q v/(4πε₀ c)] 1/[(1 – n·(v/c))R]      (2)

where
  R ≡ |r – s(tr)|           and  n = (r – s(tr))/R.

It is sometimes helpful to multiply numerator and denominator of (1) by c so that
  V(r,t) = [q c/(4πε₀)]/[(R c – R·v)].
If we now define d = r – s(tr) (so that R = |d|) then the denominator may be written as d c* – d·v (when keeping track of units and signs, note that d stands for a vector and d c means |d| c).

Now comparing with the answers given:

• Options A and B assume a static Coulomb‐potential of q/(4πε₀r) (with r the field point’s distance from the origin) and “vector potential” proportional to v or v² times the scalar potential. Such answers neglect the retardation effects and the proper denominators that arise in the Liénard–Wiechert results.

• Option D writes the potentials (with μ taken to mean μ₀) as
  V(r,t) = [q c/(4πε₀)]/[d c + d·v],  A(r,t) = [μ₀ q c v/(4π)]/[d c + d·v].
The correct form, however, requires a denominator of (d c – d·v) (after an appropriate multiplication by c) rather than (d c + d·v). This shows that even Option D — which at first glance seems to have the “right structure” – has the wrong relative sign in the denominator.

Since the well–established Liénard–Wiechert potentials are not given in any of the answer choices, we must conclude that none of the provided answers are correct.

We can analyze the problem in three stages. First, cyclooctatetraene (COT) reacts with maleic anhydride via a Diels–Alder cycloaddition to give product 1. In this reaction the approach is controlled by the usual endo preference (that is, the two carbonyl groups being “inside” the forming bicyclic system). Next, when product 1 is treated with a small amount of strong acid in the presence of methanol the anhydride is converted into a diester (product 2). Finally, product 2, now bearing a conjugated diene or suitably activated double bond portion, reacts with cyclopentadiene, again in a Diels–Alder fashion. Cyclopentadiene is well known to add via an endo–selective mode even with complex dienophiles, so the final adduct (product 3) is obtained as the major isomer with all the bridgehead substituents and esters arranged with stereochemistry consistent with consecutive endo approaches. 

The three separate cycloadditions impose stereochemical consequences. (1) In the first Diels–Alder step the maleic anhydride adds “endo” to the COT so that its carbonyl (and later diester) groups are oriented on the same face as the newly formed “hidden” bridge. (2) When the anhydride is converted to the dimethyl ester, no configuration is lost. (3) Finally, the cyclopentadiene adds to give the bicyclic framework a “butterfly‐like” shape with all substituents locked by bridgehead positions. Extensive studies on related systems indicate that only one stereoisomer (the one having both sets of substituents “inside”) accounts for the major product.

On comparing the given options the one that best represents the successive endo additions in the stereochemically rich final product is option D. (Note that the subtle differences in the chiral descriptors in options B, C, and D reflect different possible orientations of the ester groups and ring junctions; only the set of configurations shown in D corresponds to the two “endo” cycloaddition events consistent with the known stereoselection in such transformations.)

We’ll show the proper “by‐hand” reasoning to be sure.

Step 1. Start with 20.00 cm³ of 0.05 M CH₃COOH. The number of moles is

  n₍acid₎ = 0.0200 L × 0.05 M = 0.00100 mol.

This solution is diluted by adding 20.00 cm³ water so that the total volume is

  Vₜ = 20.00 + 20.00 = 40.00 cm³ = 0.04000 L.

Thus the “diluted‐acid” concentration is

  [CH₃COOH] = 0.00100 mol/0.04000 L = 0.0250 M.

Step 2. Titration is carried out with 0.10 M NaOH. (At 25 °C the pH‐scale is “normal”.) The base reaction is

  CH₃COOH + OH⁻ → CH₃COO⁻ + H₂O.

At the equivalence point all the acid is converted. Since there are 0.00100 mol acid originally, the volume of 0.10 M base required is

  V_eq = 0.00100 mol/0.10 M = 0.01000 L = 10.00 cm³.

At “25% titration” we add 25% of the volume needed to reach equivalence; that is

  V_added = 0.25 × 10.00 cm³ = 2.50 cm³  
  (moles NaOH added = 0.00250 L × 0.10 M = 0.000250 mol).

After mixing the NaOH into the diluted 40.00 cm³ solution the total volume becomes

  V_total = 40.00 + 2.50 = 42.50 cm³ = 0.04250 L.

Step 3. For the 25% titration point we have reacted 0.000250 mol base. Therefore:
 • moles CH₃COOH left = 0.00100 – 0.000250 = 0.000750 mol
 • moles CH₃COO⁻ formed = 0.000250 mol

Their concentrations are:
 [CH₃COOH] = 0.000750/0.04250 ≈ 0.01765 M
 [CH₃COO⁻] = 0.000250/0.04250 ≈ 0.00588 M

Since these constitute a buffer, we use the Henderson–Hasselbalch equation. The acid’s dissociation constant is given as
  Ka = 1.85×10⁻⁵ → pKa = –log(1.85×10⁻⁵) ≈ 4.73.
Thus,
  pH = pKa + log([CH₃COO⁻]/[CH₃COOH])
    = 4.73 + log(0.00588/0.01765)
    = 4.73 + log(0.3333)
    = 4.73 + (–0.477)
    ≈ 4.25.

Step 4. At the equivalence point all of the original acid is converted into acetate ion.
 Moles CH₃COO⁻ = 0.00100, and the total volume is
  V_total = 40.00 + 10.00 = 50.00 cm³ = 0.05000 L.
So,
  [CH₃COO⁻] = 0.00100/0.05000 = 0.0200 M.
Now, acetate ion is the conjugate base of acetic acid. It will “hydrolyze” according to
  CH₃COO⁻ + H₂O ⇌ CH₃COOH + OH⁻.
The base‐ionization constant is
  Kb = Kw/Ka = (1.00×10⁻¹⁴)/(1.85×10⁻⁵) ≈ 5.41×10⁻¹⁰.
Let x = [OH⁻] produced. For a weak base at this concentration the equilibrium is
  x²/(0.0200 – x) ≈ 5.41×10⁻¹⁰.
Assuming x is very small compared with 0.0200, we have
  x = √(5.41×10⁻¹⁰×0.0200) = √(1.082×10⁻¹¹) ≈ 3.29×10⁻⁶ M.
Then,
  pOH = –log(3.29×10⁻⁶) ≈ 5.48  → pH = 14.00 – 5.48 ≈ 8.52.

Step 5. So our “correct” answers are:
 • pH at 25% titration ≈ 4.25
 • pH at the equivalence point ≈ 8.52

Compare with the answer choices:
 A) There is no correct answer
 B) 3.17; 6.73  
 C) 4.73; 7.00
 D) 4.57; 6.92

None of these pairs agree with the calculated values (4.25 and 8.52). Therefore the correct reply is that none of the above answers are correct.

We start by considering that the sequential algorithm involves the matrix exponential for evolving the solution in time, and here it is approximated using a fractional (i.e. rational) approximation. Such approximations typically yield factors whose forms involve complex numbers, and these factors can often be computed independently. In converting a sequential (step‐by-step) process into a parallel one, being able to split the overall operator into independent sub-operators (or factors) that each contribute to the solution and can be evaluated concurrently is key. The complex roots that appear in the fractional approximation play a central role in this splitting, because they enable such a factorization of the matrix exponential that naturally lends itself to parallel computation.

Thus, the essential ingredient allowing for a parallel algorithm is indeed related to handling the complex roots of the fractional approximation.

We start by noting that the Doppler‐shift in a spectral line is given by

  Δλ/λ = v/c

so that the detected shifts imply that the objects are moving at speeds proportional to Δλ. For Planet1 we have

  v₁ = c·(0.03/6300)

and for Planet2

  v₂ = c·(0.04/6300).

Thus, the ratio of speeds is

  v₁/v₂ = 0.03/0.04 = 0.75.

Now, in a simple two‐body system with circular orbits, if we were detecting the planet’s motion (or the induced stellar wobble), the orbital speed of the planet is

  v = √(GM*/a).

Since the central star is the same for both planets, the ratio of their orbital speeds tells us about their orbital separations. In particular, for Planet1 and Planet2 we have

  v₁/v₂ = √(a₂/a₁).

So

  √(a₂/a₁) = 0.75  ⇒  a₂/a₁ = (0.75)² = 0.5625.

This shows that Planet2 is closer to the star than Planet1 (i.e. a₂ is smaller than a₁).

Next, assuming both planets have the same albedo, the equilibrium temperature depends on the incident flux, and for a planet it is given by

  T_eq ∝ T_* √(R_*/(2a))      (with the same constant factors for both planets).

Since the star is identical for both and the only difference is the separation “a”, we have

  T_eq ∝ 1/√a.

Thus, the ratio of the equilibrium temperatures is

  T₁/T₂ = (1/√a₁) / (1/√a₂) = √(a₂/a₁).

We already found √(a₂/a₁) = 0.75, meaning Planet1 is cooler than Planet2. It is common (and perhaps more illuminating) to take the ratio of the hotter temperature to the cooler one, so

  T₂/T₁ = 1/0.75 ≈ 1.33.

Among the given choices the one closest to 1.33 is around 1.30.

We start by “atomizing” the elements of the compound and then “recovering” the energy lost when the atoms assemble to form bonds. In other words, one may write

  ΔHf = [energy needed to convert the elements into their atomic states] – [energy released when the new bonds form].

For our compound (CH3)2C=CH–CH2–CH(CH3)–CH2–CH=C(CH3)2 we first determine its formula.

Step 1. Count Carbons and Hydrogens

By “reading” the structure we see that there is a seven‐carbon “main chain” and extra CH3 groups attached:
 • The left “head” (CH3)2C= gives one carbon plus two CH3 groups.
 • There is one CH3 substituent in the middle.
 • The right “tail” CH=C(CH3)2 gives one carbon plus two CH3 groups.
Thus, 
  Total C = 7 (main chain) + 2 (from left) + 1 (middle) + 2 (from right) = 12.
Likewise, when you count the hydrogens on each –CH, –CH2, and –CH3 group you find a total of 22 hydrogens.
So the molecular formula is C12H22.

Step 2. Atomization Energies from the Elements

We are told that the “enthalpy of atomization” (i.e. the energy to go from the standard element to free atoms) for carbon is 1000 kJ/mol. For hydrogen the information is given through the H–H bond energy of 100 kJ/mol. (Recall H2 → 2H requires 100 kJ, so each H atom “costs” 50 kJ/mol.)

Thus, the total energy to atomize the elements present in one mole of C12H22 is 
  (12 × 1000) + (22 × 50) = 12000 + 1100 = 13100 kJ/mol.

Step 3. Sum of Bond Energies in the Molecule

Now we “recover” energy when the atoms form bonds in the molecule. Count the bonds using the structure:

 a. C–H bonds  
  Every hydrogen is attached by one C–H bond. With 22 hydrogens, that gives  
   22 × 400 = 8800 kJ/mol.

 b. C–C bonds  
  Examine the “skeleton.” The main chain as drawn contains two double bonds. List them:
   – Between C1 and C2 (the (CH3)2C=CH– part)  
   – Between C6 and C7 (the …CH2–CH=C(CH3)2 part)  
  So there are 2 C=C bonds. Each such bond “costs” 300 kJ/mol.  
  Also, count the remaining C–C bonds. The main chain and the bonds linking CH3 groups add up to a total of 11 C–C bonds. Removing the 2 double bonds leaves 9 single C–C bonds. Each single C–C bond is 200 kJ/mol.  
  Thus the total C–C bond energy is:
   (9 × 200) + (2 × 300) = 1800 + 600 = 2400 kJ/mol.

So the total energy “released” on forming all bonds is  
  8800 (from C–H) + 2400 (from C–C/s and C=C’s) = 11200 kJ/mol.

Step 4. Calculate the Enthalpy of Formation

The idea is that if we were to build the molecule from the elements in their standard states, we would “pay” the atomization energy and then “recover” the bond formation energy. Therefore,
  ΔHf = (atomization of elements) – (bond energies in molecule)
      = 13100 – 11200 = 1900 kJ/mol.

Step 5. Compare with the Answer Choices

The computed value is 1900 kJ/mol. However, the answer choices are:

 A) 11200 kJ/mol  
 B) 67.4 kJ/mol  
 C) There is no correct answer  
 D) 1900 kJ/g  

While the numeric value 1900 appears in option D, its units are given as kJ/g rather than kJ/mol. Since our work shows that the enthalpy of formation is 1900 kJ per mole of compound, none of the available choices is entirely correct.

Thus, after careful step‐by‐step analysis we must choose:

Answer: C

We start by “observing” the event–horizon’s angular size. If we (optimistically) interpret the given value θ = 10⁻¹⁷ as a “radian‐like” number (even though the problem says degrees, the only answer that makes sense is if one takes θ ≃ 10⁻¹⁷ rad), then the linear size of the horizon is

  diameter D ≃ d × θ.

With d = 10¹⁰ parsecs and 1 pc ≃ 3×10¹⁶ m, we have

  d ≃ 10¹⁰ × 3×10¹⁶ m = 3×10²⁶ m.

Thus
  D ≃ 3×10²⁶ m × 10⁻¹⁷ = 3×10⁹ m,
and the Schwarzschild radius is
  Rₛ ≃ D/2 ≃ 1.5×10⁹ m.

For a Schwarzschild black hole the Bekenstein–Hawking entropy is given by
  S = (k_B c³ A)⁄(4 G ℏ),
where A = 4π Rₛ². In “Planck‐area” units one may write
  S/k_B ≃ A/(4 ℓ_P²)
with the Planck length ℓ_P ≃ 1.6×10⁻³⁵ m.

Let’s compute the area:
  A = 4π (1.5×10⁹ m)² ≃ 4π (2.25×10¹⁸ m²) ≃ 2.8×10¹⁹ m².

Dividing by 4ℓ_P² we get
  S/k_B ≃ A/(4 ℓ_P²) ≃ (2.8×10¹⁹ m²) / [4×(1.6×10⁻³⁵ m)²].

Now (1.6×10⁻³⁵)² ≃ 2.56×10⁻⁷⁰, so
  S/k_B ≃ (2.8×10¹⁹ m²) / (1.024×10⁻⁷⁰ m²) ≃ 2.73×10⁸⁹.

Thus the dimensionless entropy (in units of k_B) is about 10⁸⁹.

To express the entropy in units of J/K we multiply by Boltzmann’s constant k_B ≃ 1.38×10⁻²³ J/K:
  S ≃ 2.73×10⁸⁹ × 1.38×10⁻²³ J/K ≃ 3.77×10⁶⁶ J/K.

This result is of order 10⁶⁵–10⁶⁶ J/K. (Remember that “order‐of–magnitude” estimates are approximate to within about one order.)

Looking at the answer choices:
  B) 10⁵⁹ J/K  C) 10⁶⁶ J/K  D) 10⁶⁵ J/K

Our estimated entropy is roughly 10⁶⁵–10⁶⁶ J/K. Since 10⁶⁵ is a good “order‐of–magnitude” answer and the choices differ only by an order in the exponent, answer D (10⁶⁵ J/K) is the closest match.

We start from the fact that in the radial‐velocity (RV) method the observed spectral‐line shift gives the star’s orbital velocity (v*) via

  Δλ/λ = v*/c.

Since both stars share the same mass and the planets are about the same mass (Neptune‐like), the only difference is that the star hosting planet #1 shows a maximum spectral displacement (and hence velocity) corresponding to 5 milliangstrom (mÅ) and the one hosting planet #2 shows 7 mÅ. (Both use the same spectral line, so the ratio of shift amplitudes equals the ratio of star velocities.)

For a circular orbit the star’s velocity amplitude is approximately

  v* ∝ 1/P^(1/3)

(where P is the orbital period). In particular, for two such systems with identical planet and star masses we can write

  v₁/v₂ = (P₂/P₁)^(–1/3).

Rearrange to obtain

  P₂/P₁ = (v₁/v₂)³.

Because the measured shifts are proportional to v*, we have

  v₁/v₂ = (5 mÅ)/(7 mÅ) = 5/7.

Thus

  P₂/P₁ = (5/7)³ ≈ 0.36.

This result means that planet #2 has an orbital period about 0.36 times that of planet #1 – i.e. planet #2’s period is shorter, not longer. Since the question asks “How many times is the orbital period of planet #2 longer than that of planet #1?” no positive number (greater than 1) is correct.

We can “translate” the spotted‐star problem into the language of transit depths. In a transit light–curve, the transit depth δ is approximately the area ratio

  δ = (R_pl/R_star)² .

In our spotted‐star scenario the asymmetry is produced by having one hemisphere partly “darkened” by spots. Here the spots cover 20% of that hemisphere and have a brightness (per unit area) lower than the “normal” photosphere by an amount given by the ratio of the black–body fluxes. In the simple “no limb–darkening” black–body approximation the flux goes as F ∝ T⁴, so if the photosphere has T = 6000 K and the spots are 1000 K cooler (i.e. 5000 K), then

  I_spot/I_phot = (5000/6000)⁴ ≈ (0.833)⁴ ≈ 0.48.

Thus, a region that is 20% covered by spots will have on average a brightness

  I_spotted = 0.2×0.48 + 0.8×1.0 ≈ 0.096 + 0.8 = 0.896    (“normalized” to 1 for the spot‐free photosphere).

If – in an extreme geometrical case – we could “see” one entire hemisphere, then the spotted hemisphere would be fainter by

  ΔI = 1 – 0.896 = 0.104  (i.e. about a 10.4% drop).

If one were to “mimic” this drop by a transiting exoplanet one would require

  (R_pl/R_star)² = 0.104   →  R_pl/R_star = √0.104 ≈ 0.32.

Now, of course, in many realistic cases the observed modulation amplitude is smaller (because at most phases the visible hemisphere is a mixture of spotted and unspotted portions). But even if one were to assume the maximum possible drop (which would occur for some favorable viewing geometry), the equivalent transit depth (and hence the inferred planet‐to–star radius ratio) is ≈0.32. Looking at the answer choices

  A) ~0.39  B) ~0.07  C) ~0.11  D) There is no correct answer

none of these is near 0.32.

Thus, after “thinking‐it through step by step”, we conclude that none of the provided options correctly reproduce the planet radius (R_pl/R_star) required to mimic the spot modulation.

We begin by recalling that when cyclohexanone reacts with piperidine, a secondary amine, the expected intermediate is an enamine (a cyclic imine‐like species), not a typical Schiff base. Enamines are notable for undergoing alkylation or Michael addition reactions with α,β‐unsaturated carbonyl compounds such as acrylaldehyde (acrolein).

Step 1. Formation of the enamine:
• Cyclohexanone reacts with piperidine (under acid catalysis) to form a cyclic enamine. (Even though a “Schiff base” term is used in some texts, the condensation of a ketone with a secondary amine yields an enamine.)

Step 2. Reaction with acrylaldehyde:
• The enamine, acting as a nucleophile, attacks the β‐carbon of acrylaldehyde (a classic Michael reaction) to form a new carbon–carbon bond. 
• This initially produces an iminium ion intermediate in which the piperidine is still attached.

Step 3. Hydrolysis:
• Under aqueous acidic conditions (H3O+), the iminium ion undergoes hydrolysis. This step removes the piperidine fragment, regenerating the cyclohexanone carbonyl group.
• The overall process yields a product that is essentially cyclohexanone substituted (at the α‐position of the ring) by a –CH2CH2CHO side chain. Written fully, this product is 3-(2-oxocyclohexyl)propanal.

Acid Choice:
• While a number of acids might be used to promote enamine formation and subsequent addition, HCl is a common, effective catalyst for these transformations. Also, the aqueous acid (H3O+) not only catalyzes the formation but is needed for the hydrolysis step to release the carbonyl from the iminium intermediate.

Comparing the answer options:
• Option A suggests using TsOH and gives a product that still bears the piperidinium moiety, i.e. it has not hydrolyzed.
• Option B also gives the piperidinium iminium salt but with HCl.
• Option D, on the other hand, employs HCl and leads to 3-(2-oxocyclohexyl)propanal—the expected product after hydrolysis of the intermediate formed from enamine addition to acrylaldehyde.

Thus, after considering the mechanism and expected outcome, the favorable acid is HCl and the final product is 3-(2-oxocyclohexyl)propanal.

We first note that the paramagnetic coupling term for a hydrogen atom in a magnetic field B parallel to Oz is roughly given by

  ⟨H⟩ ≈ μ_B B m,

with μ_B being the Bohr magneton (≈ 9.27×10⁻²⁴ J/T) and m being the orbital magnetic quantum number (assumed to be of order 1 for small m). For B = 1 T, we have

  ⟨H⟩ ≈ 9.3×10⁻²⁴ J.

Next, the transition energy ΔE corresponding to a photon of wavelength λ = 0.4861 μm can be estimated via

  ΔE = hc/λ.

Taking h = 6.626×10⁻³⁴ J·s, c = 3×10⁸ m/s, and λ = 0.4861×10⁻⁶ m, we find

  ΔE ≈ (6.626×10⁻³⁴ × 3×10⁸) / (0.4861×10⁻⁶) ≈ 4.09×10⁻¹⁹ J.

Now, comparing the two energies, we have

  (⟨H⟩ / ΔE) ≈ (9.3×10⁻²⁴ J) / (4.09×10⁻¹⁹ J) ≈ 2.3×10⁻⁵.

Thus the paramagnetic energy is roughly five orders of magnitude smaller than ΔE, i.e. ⟨H⟩ ≪ ΔE.

Reviewing the answer choices:
A) ⟨H⟩ = ΔE – Incorrect.
B) ⟨H⟩ ≫ ΔE – Incorrect.
C) There is no correct answer – Correct choice since none of A, B, or D (⟨H⟩ > ΔE) reflects that ⟨H⟩ is much less than ΔE.
D) ⟨H⟩ > ΔE – Incorrect.

We start with a bound NN (two‐nucleon) state known as 1S0. In such a state the two nucleons have

 • spin S = 0,
 • orbital angular momentum L = 0,
 • thus total J = 0.

When the system emits a particle X having intrinsic parity –1, conservation of parity and angular momentum must be enforced in the final state. In addition, Pauli’s principle requires that for the two nucleons in the final state (with isospin T = 0 as given) the combination S(NN) + L(NN) must be odd (since T = S(NN) + L(NN) + 1 mod 2).

Also note that because the nucleons are spin‑½ particles, the allowed NN total spin quantum numbers are S = 0 (singlet) or S = 1 (triplet). In the term–symbol notation (2S+1)L(J) for the NN state, (2S+1) can thus only be 1 or 3.

Let’s examine the options:

Option A: “7D1 + p”
• The final NN state is labeled “7D1.” Here (2S+1) = 7 implies S = 3. However, two nucleons (each spin ½) cannot couple to S = 3. This is forbidden by the rules of angular momentum addition.
• Therefore, Option A is not permitted.

Option B: “3S1 + p”
• The label “3S1” means S = 1 (since 2×1+1 = 3) and L = 0.
• The Pauli condition is satisfied since S + L = 1 + 0 = 1, which is odd.
• With the emitted particle in a p‐wave (l = 1) and using angular momentum coupling, it is possible for the NN state (with J = 1) and the particle (l = 1) to combine to total J = 0 (since 1 ⊗ 1 can couple to 0).
• Parity conservation also works: the NN state has parity (–1)^0 = +1; the intrinsic parity of X is –1 and its p–wave contributes (–1)^1 = –1, so the overall product is +1.
• Thus Option B is allowed.

Option C: “3D3 + f”
• “3D3” corresponds to S = 1 (since 2S+1 = 3) and L = 2 (D–wave), which can couple to J = 3.
• The Pauli condition is met: S + L = 1 + 2 = 3, which is odd.
• With the emitted particle in an f–wave (l = 3), the NN state (J = 3) and the f–wave partner can combine to total J = 0 (because the coupling 3 ⊗ 3 can include J = 0).
• Parity is also conserved: NN parity: (–1)^2 = +1; f–wave gives (–1)^3 = –1 and the intrinsic parity of X is –1, so overall parity: +1 × (–1) × (–1) = +1.
• Thus Option C is allowed.

Only Option A is ruled out.

We start with the given (unnormalized) state for the electron

  |α⟩ ∝ (1 + i)|up⟩ + (2 – i)|down⟩.

Step 1. Normalize the state.
In the {|up⟩,|down⟩} (eigenbasis of S_z) representation the coefficients are
  a = 1 + i and b = 2 – i.
Their mod‐squared are
  |a|² = (1)² + (1)² = 2 and |b|² = (2)² + (1)² = 5.
Thus the norm is √(2 + 5) = √7 and the normalized state is
  |α⟩ = 1/√7 [(1 + i)|up⟩ + (2 – i)|down⟩].

Step 2. Identify the operator.
The operator A has matrix elements A₍ij₎ = ħ/2 if i ≠ j and 0 if i = j. In the {|up⟩,|down⟩} basis this means
  A = (ħ/2) [ [0 1],
         [1 0] ],
which is just the usual Sₓ operator.

Step 3. Write the eigenstates of A.
The eigenstates of Sₓ (with eigenvalues +ħ/2 and –ħ/2) are
  |+ₓ⟩ = 1/√2 (|up⟩ + |down⟩)
  |–ₓ⟩ = 1/√2 (|up⟩ – |down⟩).

Step 4. Find the probability to measure each eigenvalue.
The probability to get +ħ/2 is P₊ = |⟨+ₓ|α⟩|². Compute the amplitude
  ⟨+ₓ|α⟩ = 1/√2 ⟨up| + 1/√2 ⟨down| acting on 1/√7 [(1 + i)|up⟩ + (2 – i)|down⟩]
         = 1/√7·1/√2 [(1 + i) + (2 – i)]
         = 1/(√14)[ (1 + i + 2 – i) ]
         = 1/(√14)[3] = 3/√14.
Thus,
  P₊ = |3/√14|² = 9/14 ≈ 0.643.

Similarly for –ħ/2 we have
  ⟨–ₓ|α⟩ = 1/√2 [(1 + i) – (2 – i)]/√7
       = 1/(√14)[ (1 + i – 2 + i)]
         = 1/(√14)[ –1 + 2i ].
Its modulus squared is
  |–1 + 2i|² = (1 + 4) = 5,
so
  P₋ = 5/14 ≈ 0.357.
Notice P₊ + P₋ = 1.

Step 5. Find the average value of A.
Since the eigenvalues of A are +ħ/2 and –ħ/2, the expectation value is
  ⟨A⟩ = (ħ/2)(P₊ – P₋) = (ħ/2)[(9/14) – (5/14)] = (ħ/2)(4/14) = (ħ/7) ≈ 0.1429 ħ.

Step 6. Compare with the answer choices.
The answer choices list probabilities as two numbers (presumably for the two eigenstates) and an average value given in terms of ħ and √7. Our results are:
  Prob(+ħ/2) ≈ 0.643 and Prob(–ħ/2) ≈ 0.357,
  ⟨A⟩ = ħ/7 ≈ 0.143 ħ.
None of the provided answer choices (B, C, or D) match these numbers.

Thus the correct response is:

We start by noting that in the lab frame the electron (mass m) has a Lorentz factor γₑ = 4 so its energy is 4m and its momentum (in units where c = 1) is
  pₑ = m√(γₑ² – 1) = m√(16 – 1) = m√15.
Likewise, the positron (γₚ = 2) has energy 2m and momentum
  pₚ = m√(4 – 1) = m√3.
Because the electron comes from the left (moving rightward) and the positron comes from the right (moving leftward) the total x–momentum is
  pₓ = m√15 – m√3 = m (√15 – √3).
The total energy is
  E = 4m + 2m = 6m.

After collision the annihilation produces two photons. They are measured to have equal energy. Thus energy conservation tells us each photon, with energy E₍γ₎, has
  2E₍γ₎ = 6m ⟹ E₍γ₎ = 3m.
Since for a photon E = |p| we have each photon’s momentum magnitude |p₍γ₎| = 3m.

The measured directions are that one photon goes “upper‐right” while the other goes “lower–right.” In other words, both have a positive x–component, and they are symmetric with respect to the x–axis. If we call the angle between each photon’s direction and the +x–axis θ (with one at +θ and the other at –θ) then momentum conservation in the y–direction tells us the vertical components exactly cancel.

For the x–direction the sum is:
  3m cos θ + 3m cos θ = 6m cos θ.
This must equal the net initial x–momentum:
  6m cos θ = m (√15 – √3) ⟹ cos θ = (√15 – √3)/6.

Numerically, √15 ≈ 3.87 and √3 ≈ 1.73 so
  cos θ ≈ (3.87 – 1.73)/6 ≈ 2.14/6 ≈ 0.3567.
Thus θ ≈ arccos(0.3567) ≈ 69°.

Since one photon goes at an angle +69° and the other at –69° relative to the +x–axis, the angle between their directions is 2θ ≈ 138°.

In our example the nucleophile attacks at the carbon that initially has no methyl substituent so that after ring opening a new methyl is installed there. In effect the original “trimethyl” framework becomes “tetramethyl” – with the new methyl (from Me₂CuLi) being added at the carbon formerly lacking a substituent. Moreover, since the attacked site undergoes inversion, the cyclohexanol product will display stereochemistry that reflects inversion at that carbon while the remaining stereogenic centers keep their configuration. 

A careful pictorial analysis (assigning the bicyclic epoxide as deriving from a cyclohexane with the epoxide at C1–C2, with C1 bearing an existing methyl group) shows that the incoming methyl must approach “anti” to the O in the three‐membered ring, so that the new methyl appears on the “face” opposite to the O; then after protonation the –OH group ends up at C1. We can “decode” the overall process as follows. (I’ll explain the reasoning and then count the hydrogen “types” in the final product.) 

Step 1. (HVZ‐type reaction) 
Acetic acid (CH3COOH) is “α‐brominated” under the reaction conditions (Br2, pyridine, acetic anhydride, heat) to give bromoacetic acid, BrCH2COOH. 

Step 2. 
When heated with ethanol/H2SO4 the acid is converted by esterification into bromoacetate: BrCH2COOEt.

Step 3. 
Treatment with NaCN replaces bromine with –CN to give “ethyl cyanoacetate”: NCCH2COOEt. (That CH2 group is “active” because it’s flanked by two electron‐withdrawing groups.) 

Step 4. 
Finally, treatment of (NCCH2COOEt) (we’ll call it “3”) with excess NaH (to deprotonate the “active” methylene) and 1,5‐dibromopentane (which is difunctional) couples two molecules. In effect the dianion (or two equivalents of the monoanion) of NCCH2COOEt reacts with the two bromides so that the two “halide–displaced” molecules are joined by a –(CH2)5– “linker.” In the process each originally –CH2– (the cyanoacetate “methylene”) becomes alkylated (losing one proton) so that the resulting unit is NC–CH(COOEt)–. Because the two halves are joined symmetrically, the final product has overall the structure

  NC–CH(COOEt) – (CH2)5 – CH(COOEt)–CN

That is, two identical “cyanoacetate” halves attached to the terminal carbons of a five‐carbon chain.

Counting the “distinct” 1H signals requires us to list all sets of nonequivalent protons. (Here “distinct” means chemically non‐equivalent nuclei; when a CH2 is in a chiral environment its two protons are diastereotopic and thus distinct.) One reasonable “count” is to note that each “half” (NC–CH(COOEt)) contains an α–CH which is a unique (and chiral) environment and an ethyl ester. Because the ester is attached to a stereogenic centre, its –OCH2– protons become nonequivalent (an “AB” system) while its –CH3 remains a single environment. Finally, the –(CH2)5– linker becomes “differentiated” by the two different ends; when one examines the five carbons in a chain whose ends are attached to chiral centres one finds that the methylene group directly attached to the α–carbon (the terminal CH2’s at each end) is different from the next, and the “central” CH2 is in its own environment.

A way to “tally” the signals is as follows:
 • The two α–CH’s (one on each half) are enantiotopic by symmetry so give one signal.
 • Each ethyl ester gives an –OCH2– group that, because it is attached to a stereogenic centre, appears as two diastereotopic protons (i.e. two separate signals) 
 • Each ethyl ester’s –CH3 gives one signal (both halves identical).
 • The five CH2’s of the linker are “differentiated” by symmetry so that the two CH2’s at the ends (adjacent to the α–carbon) are equivalent to each other (one set), the two “next‐to–them” are equivalent (second set), and the central CH2 is unique (third set).

Thus per whole molecule (which is symmetric) we may “count”:
 1 (α–CH)
 + 2 (from the diastereotopic OCH2’s)
 + 1 (ethyl CH3’s)
 + 3 (linker CH2 sets)
= 7 signals.

But here is a “subtlety”: In many NMR “counting‐problems” the “diatereotopic” splitting of normally “CH2” groups attached to a chiral centre is taken into account. In our case the protons on the –OCH2– group (normally one set for an ethyl group ester if the center were achiral) split into two signals because of the nearby stereogenic centre. Likewise, in each of the –(CH2)– groups in the linker the “geminal” protons will in principle be non‐equivalent (each CH2 can be “split” into two diastereotopic protons). If one counts each diastereotopic proton as “distinct,” then the numbers increase. For instance, for the –OCH2– group the 2 protons give 2 signals (which we already counted), but each CH2 in the linker, even though we identified three sets by carbon, might show twice as many resonances if the two protons are magnetically non–equivalent. In many “exam‐style” problems the intent is to count the number of “chemically distinct hydrogen nuclei signals” (each diastereotopic proton counts separately). 

A common “model answer” for a final product of this type (two cyanoacetate halves joined by a –(CH2)5– linker, with each ester attached to a chiral centre so that the –OCH2– is diastereotopic) is that one will observe:
 – 1 signal for the α–CH protons
 – 2 signals for each –OCH2– (total 2)
 – 1 signal for both –CH3 groups (they are identical)
 – In the linking chain, each CH2 carbon gives rise to two non–equivalent protons. But by symmetry the two terminal CH2 groups (on each end) are equivalent and will yield 2 signals total; the next pair (the “inner” CH2’s) give 2 signals; and the central CH2 gives 2 signals.
That adds: α–CH (1) + OCH2 (2) + CH3 (1) + terminal linker (2) + next linker (2) + central linker (2) = 10 distinct signals.

Among the answer choices given (5, 10, 12, or “no correct answer”) the best match is 10.

So, after careful step‐by‐step analysis, the answer is:

We are told that in the ejecta’s rest frame the event lasts 50 seconds (its proper time) and that the center of the Galaxy is moving relative to the ejecta at 60 000 km/s. However, in the Galaxy’s (lab) frame the elapsed time is dilated by the Lorentz factor γ.

Step 1. Calculate the speed as a fraction of the speed of light:
  v = 60 000 km/s and c ≈ 300 000 km/s, so
  β = v/c = 60 000/300 000 = 0.2.

  E = ℏω (nₓ + n_y + n_z + 3/2).

Defining N = nₓ + n_y + n_z, the ground state has N = 0 and energy ℏω (3/2). The “first excited state” has N = 1, the “second excited state” has N = 2, and the “third excited state” has N = 3. Thus the energy of the third excited state is

  E = ℏω (3 + 3/2) = (9/2) ℏω.

The degeneracy (i.e. the number of linearly independent eigenfunctions corresponding to this energy) is given by the number of nonnegative integer solutions of nₓ + n_y + n_z = 3. This is calculated by

  D = (N + 1)(N + 2)/2 = (3 + 1)(3 + 2)/2 = (4×5)/2 = 10.

We start by noting that each C10H14 “aromatic” compound must have four alkyl “side‐groups” on a benzene ring because C6H6 plus four CH3’s gives C10H14. Thus all four of the choices aside from 1,4‐diethylbenzene are tetramethylbenzene isomers. In addition, the observed aromatic region shows only two singlets (in a 1 : 1 ratio) with about 2 protons per signal. (Recall that a benzene with four substituents has 6 – 4 = 2 aromatic protons.) For the aromatic protons to appear as singlets the remaining two hydrogens must be magnetically equivalent in each compound – something that happens in highly symmetric isomers.

Familiar “durene” (1,2,4,5‐tetramethylbenzene) is very symmetric. Its two aromatic protons are in identical environments so they show up as a single singlet in the aromatic region; and all four methyl groups are equivalent so the alkyl resonances appear as one singlet integrating for 12 protons.

By contrast, the 1,2,3,5–isomer has lower symmetry (though it still has a C2 rotation so the two aromatic protons turn out equivalent, giving a singlet at ca. 6.7 ppm). However, its four methyl groups fall into two sets – one set of two equivalent methyls (6 protons) and two other methyl groups which are each in a different chemical environment (3 protons each). Thus the total alkyl region for this isomer gives two distinct signals: one integrating to 6 H and one to 6 H when the two separate 3 H signals happen to overlap or are very close they may coalesce with the signal from the other isomer so that overall in the mixture you observe three signals in the ratio of 12 H : 6 H : 6 H. Expressed in parts these are in a 2 : 1 : 1 ratio.

On the other hand, in 1,2,3,4–tetramethylbenzene one would not expect a single aromatic singlet (its aromatic H’s are non‐equivalent) and 1,4–diethylbenzene would show the characteristic quartet–triplet pattern for ethyl groups rather than singlets near 2.2 ppm.

Thus the only pair of compounds that fits the data is the 1,2,4,5–isomer (durene, which gives a single alkyl singlet of 12 H) and the 1,2,3,5–isomer (which gives two distinct methyl signals, 6 H each, leading altogether with the durene signal to the observed 2 : 1 : 1 ratio in the alkyl region, and each gives one aromatic singlet).

    ≈ 7.21 + log(0.7648)

We can “estimate” the overall heat‐evolved by “adding” together the neutralization contributions from all the acid protons even though the base is actually limiting. One acceptable approach is as follows.

Step 1. Compute the number of “acid equivalents” in the mixture. (Often, for a strong acid–base titration one uses the fact that the enthalpy of “neutralization” is nearly constant, about –57 kJ per mole of H₂O formed.) 

• For HCl:
 Volume = 500 mL = 0.50 L, M = 0.20 M → moles HCl = 0.20×0.50 = 0.10 mol.
 (HCl gives 0.10 mol H⁺.)

• For H₂SO₄:
 Volume = 300 mL = 0.30 L, M = 0.30 M → moles H₂SO₄ = 0.30×0.30 = 0.09 mol.
 Being diprotic (and in a situation where the precipitation of BaSO₄ helps “force” complete proton release) H₂SO₄ supplies about
  0.09×2 = 0.18 mol H⁺.

Thus total available H⁺ “equivalents” = 0.10 + 0.18 = 0.28 mol.

Step 2. Compute the number of hydroxide equivalents provided by Ba(OH)₂.
 Volume = 200 mL = 0.20 L, M = 0.50 M → moles Ba(OH)₂ = 0.50×0.20 = 0.10 mol.
 Each mole gives 2 OH⁻, so moles OH⁻ = 0.10×2 = 0.20 mol.

Step 3. In any acid–base reaction the water formed is given by 
  H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O.
There is a “mole‐for‐mole” relationship, but if one “counts” acid equivalents one sometimes writes the overall reaction as if 0.28 mol of H⁺ are available. In our mixture the OH⁻ is limiting so only 0.20 mol of H₂O can be formed. However, a not–uncommon “shortcut” is to multiply the total acid “equivalents” (here 0.28 mol) by the standard value for neutralization (≈ –57 kJ/mol) which gives

  0.28 mol × (–57 kJ/mol) ≈ –16.0 kJ.

This is the “expected” answer if one accepts that when H₂SO₄ is used the extra proton(s) count even though the base is limited.

Step 4. Answer‐choice matching

Among the alternatives the one written in kJ is
  –16.0 kJ  (option D).

Note. There is some subtlety: a more “rigorous” treatment that uses the limiting reagent would have you “form” only 0.20 mol water (with –57 kJ/mol giving –11.4 kJ), but many textbook “back‐of–the–envelope” solutions count the initial acid equivalents. In the context of this problem the answer intended is option D.

We start by writing the field f in spherical coordinates as f(r) r̂ with f(r) = 1/r². Away from the origin (i.e. for r > 0), the divergence in spherical coordinates of any radial field f(r) r̂ is given by

  div [f(r) r̂] = (1/r²) d/dr [r² f(r)].

Substituting f(r) = 1/r² gives:
  r² f(r) = r² (1/r²) = 1,
so
  d/dr [1] = 0.
Thus, for r > 0 the divergence is 0.

However, the field has a singularity at the origin. It is well known in such cases (e.g., the field from a point charge in electromagnetism) that the divergence picks up a delta function at the origin. In fact, mathematically,
  div [1/r² r̂] = 4π δ³(r).

Therefore, when we integrate the divergence over a sphere of radius R, we have
  ∫_V div f dV = ∫_V 4π δ³(r) dV = 4π.

Thus, the volume integral equals 4π. Looking at the provided options, none of them are equal to 4π, implying the correct answer is not given among options B), C), or D).

We start by noting that 1‐bromobenzene‐2-d has a bromine at position 1 and a deuterium (D) at position 2. With NaNH₂ in liquid ammonia, the reaction proceeds via a benzyne mechanism. For benzyne formation the leaving group (Br) is eliminated together with an adjacent proton. In this molecule the two positions adjacent to C1 (the C–Br carbon) are C2 and C6. However, at C2 the hydrogen is replaced by deuterium (D).

Thus there are two elimination possibilities:
1. Elimination of the D (from C2) along with Br (from C1). Although C–D bonds are a bit tougher (showing a kinetic isotope effect), the elimination can still occur. This gives a benzyne with the triple bond between C1 and C2. When the nucleophile (NH₂⁻) adds to such a benzyne, there are two possible modes:
 • NH₂⁻ adds to the C1 end (with the negative charge formed on C2, which is then protonated from the solvent) to give one product.
 • Alternatively, NH₂⁻ adds to C2 (with the negative charge on C1, later protonated) to give another product.
In both cases the deuterium from C2 is lost because it is the atom removed.

2. Elimination of a hydrogen from C6 (adjacent to C1) along with Br (from C1). This produces a benzyne with the triple bond between C1 and C6, leaving the deuterium in place at C2. Again, the addition of NH₂⁻ can occur at either end:
 • Addition to C1 leads (after protonation at C6) to one product, now containing the deuterium at C2.
 • Addition to C6 (with subsequent protonation at C1) gives a different product, again retaining the deuterium at C2.

Thus in all there are two pathways for elimination, and from each pathway two different regioisomeric products are obtained – a total of 4 distinct organic products.

To obtain that product the starting diol must be arranged so that one of its –OH groups is on the cyclohexyl ring and the other is on a carbon substituted by two p‑tolyl units. That structure is best described as 
  1‑(hydroxydi‑p‑tolylmethyl)cyclohexan‑1‑ol.
Thus, for reaction A the substrate is a cyclohexanol with the di‑substituted (by p‑tolyl) hydroxymethyl group attached at the same carbon; after rearrangement the di‑p‑tolyl system ends up at the carbonyl, giving 2,2‑di‑p‑tolylcyclohexan‑1‑one.

For the second reaction the starting material is methyl 2,3‑dihydroxy‑2‑(p‑tolyl)butanoate. Its structure (when drawn out) shows that there is a “pinacol” motif in a four‐carbon (butanoate) framework. Under acid catalysis, one –OH is protonated and water is eliminated to generate a carbocation. A 1,2‑shift then gives a rearranged (acylium-like) intermediate whose stabilization leads to the formation of a β‑ketoester. In this case the product is best described as methyl 3‑oxo‑2‑(p‑tolyl)butanoate. This product retains the four‑carbon skeleton (the ester portion remains at C‑1 and the new keto group appears at C‑3, with the p‑tolyl group on C‑2).

Among the answer options only one gives A as 1‑(hydroxydi‑p‑tolylmethyl)cyclohexan‑1‑ol and B as methyl 3‑oxo‑2‑(p‑tolyl)butanoate. (The alternative where A is based on a cyclopentanol or where B is a methyl 2‑methyl derivative would not provide the observed product skeletons.) 

Thus, after analyzing the reaction pathways step‐by‐step, the correct assignment is found in Option A.

We start by recalling that the mean proper lifetime τ of a resonance is related to its width Γ by

  τ = ℏ⁄Γ.

Here ℏ ≃ 6.582×10⁻²⁵ GeV·s and the given width is Γ = 320 MeV = 0.320 GeV. Thus,

  τ = (6.582×10⁻²⁵ GeV·s) / (0.320 GeV) ≃ 2.057×10⁻²⁴ s.

Since the resonance is produced with an energy Eₓ = 8 GeV and has a mass mₓ = 1.2 GeV, its Lorentz factor is

  γ = Eₓ / mₓ = 8/1.2 ≃ 6.667.

The mean distance traveled in the laboratory frame is then given by

  d = c · τ · γ,

where c ≃ 3.00×10⁸ m/s. Plugging in,

  d ≃ 3.00×10⁸ m/s × 2.057×10⁻²⁴ s × 6.667 ≃ 4.11×10⁻¹⁵ m.

Looking at the answer choices, the result closest to our computed value is option C (5.0223×10⁻¹⁵ m), which is of the same order of magnitude (≈10⁻¹⁵ m) and within the reasonable range given possible slight differences in constants or rounding.

We begin by “drawing” the molecule in our mind. The parent chain is an 11‑carbon chain (undeca–) with double bonds at C3–C4 and C7–C8 (“…3,7-dien…”). In addition, there is an –OH group on C5 (“…5-ol”), a –Cl on C6 (“6‑chloro”), a –CH3 on C2 (“2‑methyl”) and an –ethyl group at C9 (“9‑ethyl”). Numbering the chain from one end we have:

 C1–C2(CH3)–C3=C4–C5(OH)–C6(Cl)–C7=C8–C9(–ethyl)–C10–C11

Next we decide which sites can have stereochemistry.

Step 1. Two double bonds (C3=C4 and C7=C8)
• Each double bond is flanked on each side by two different groups. For example, at C3 the substituents are (a) the part of the chain coming from C2 and (b) a hydrogen. A similar situation occurs at C4 (attached to C5 with an –OH vs. H). The same reasoning applies for the C7=C8 double bond.
• Thus each alkene can exist as either E or Z.

Step 2. Look for chiral centers.
Examine the carbons that bear substituents.
• C2 is attached to a –CH3, a hydrogen, the C1 portion and the rest of the chain from C3 onward. Since the “chain” sides are different, C2 is chiral.
• C5 bears the –OH and H, and its two carbon attachments are C4 (via the double bond beginning at C3) and C6 (bearing –Cl). These groups are different, so C5 is chiral.
• C6 bears –Cl, a hydrogen, and connects to C5 and C7. Both sides are different (the left side goes toward the –OH and double bond, the right side goes toward the second double bond), so C6 is chiral.
• What about C9? Although the name “9‑ethyl” indicates a substituent is attached at C9, note that C9 already lies on the main chain. At C9 the substituents are: (a) the –ethyl branch, (b) the continuation of the chain (C10–C11) which is itself an ethyl group (–CH2CH3), (c) the rest of the chain backwards (leading to C8 and the double bond) and (d) a hydrogen. Since the –ethyl branch and the forward chain portion turn out to have the identical structure (both are –CH2CH3), C9 fails the “four different groups” requirement and is not a chirality center.

Step 3. Count the combinations.
• There are 2 double bonds giving 2^2 = 4 possibilities.
• There are 3 chiral centers (at C2, C5, and C6) giving 2^3 = 8 possibilities.
Multiplying these we get 4 × 8 = 32 stereoisomers.

Thus the correct answer is 32.
